comments.commentBody:
Looks like Komen's recent grant to Penn State violates their new "rule" since the school is under investigation for their coverup of child rape. Want to bet $7.5 million they find a way to keep those funds in place???

Komen's $7.5 Million Grant to Penn State Appears to Violate New Policy
http://motherjones.com/mojo/2012/02/komen-foundation-gave-75-million-gra...

I read in The Atlantic that the prohibition on funding organizations that are "under investigation" was invented to give Komen an excuse to ditch Planned Parenthood, and that no other organization has ever been ditched under that rule.

Matthew's argument below (that there are other avenues for screening but the babies don't have a choice) is illogical. Poor people often don't have other avenues for screening. That's why Planned Parenthood is so important.

Fortunately, I have many avenues for donating money to fight cancer. From now on, I'll exercise them. Bye bye Komen.

It is interesting to see that traditional car companies are joining the alternative mobility market. This is also happening in peer-to-peer car rental (see companies like http://www.getaround.com/ in the US, http://www.rent-n-roll.de/ in Germany and http://www.whipcar.com/ in Great Britain), where GM has started to collaborate with RelayRides by enabling private carsharing by its OnStar technology. Interesting development, let's see how things turn out...

The Komen explanation is so obviously hollow and transparent.  This is clearly the politicization of what might have been a useful charity.  No more Komen "runs for the cure" in my community!!  They can stay in North Dallas with their other wealthy chums!!

Well said.  Although I don't believe PP would be stupid enough to use its federal funds for abortion when it is clearly prohibited from doing so, the larger question is, what happened to the concept, innocent until proven guilty?
The GOP is famous for their investigations.........of the democrats or any organizations they don't like.

Another aspect of this is if one member of Congress wants an organization investigated, it loses financially regardless of the eventual findings.  It's a new form of witch hunt with terrible consequences.

I've supported Komen enthusiastically in the past. No more. They have chosen to force poor women to choose between breast health and family services. They deserve all the bad press they get for polticizing health care.

Marie Curie for the prevention of radiation poisoning makes sense.  I have been cutting out breast cancers for 20 years and I have no idea who Susan Komen was except another another unfortunate victim.  The politicization of this by the right wing makes me sick.

Hopefully this will be the beginning of the end of so-called "conservatives" attempting to run all Americans' lives as they see fit, and they alone.  Wake up America - a hypocritical, immoral minority is attempting to turn back the clock in this country to 1950! Stop the madness, fight back, and don't let it happen!

Not another dime for Komen.

5 stars to an event that can easily redirect to push back the religious intrusion into healthcare and health decisions that need to remain between a woman and her doctor.

How you can expect anyone to believe this disingenuous (and badly written) claim of being "misquoted or misunderstood" is beyond me, and makes me doubt your competence to be in a responsible position at a foundation doing such important work (though in many ways I'm actually grateful you're so unskillful a spin artist). Do you actually expect anyone to believe that it just happened that you "focused on creating a Citeria [sic] for grants" that "unfortunately" just happened to "hit" PP and other right-wing betes noires? Really? And you're really surprised and offended that PP and its many supporters are fighting back? Seriously? We're supposed to buy this transparent pretense as well? Maybe the folks in Texarkana agree with you, but I think you've insulted them, everyone else who reads your comments, and, actually, most of all, the women of America.

SKG will from now on be known as the foundation that pioneered an entrepreneurial, commercialized model to achieve tremendous success in uniting the women (and men) of America in common cause to fight a dread disease until it turned into (or turned out to be) just another right-wing front group. The only way to "depolitize [sic] this discussion" is for you to resign. You guys are the only ones who politicized it in the first place.

John,

I stand with you in your stewardship decision and, more importantly, in your right to make such decisions.

I find it appalling that so many seem to believe that a particular recipient (in this case Planned Parenthood, but there is a bigger principle at work here) is endlessly entitled to money from a grant-maker.

Perhaps organizations that make such grants should consider the meaning of this outcry. The rights of grant-making entities seem to have been lost in all of this. If you lose the right to make your own rules, how are you to carry out your mission?

Thank you for the good work you do at SKG.

On your first point, I don't think the article stated that your opinions were those of SKG. On your second point, you cannot hide behind semantics. Whether PPH was "the focus" or "a focus" or "one of many" similar targets - I'm pretty sure it doesn't matter whether you used a shotgun or a sniper rifle, the damage is done.

Gardner,

I think you have misquoted me or misunderstood what i said. First, I was very clear that my comments were solely my own opinion and not that of SKG. Second,
i never said that we made the change to specifically end our relationship with PPH. To the contrary, i told both you and Pam that PPH was never the focus of the board discussions but that we focused on creating a Citeria for grants in the new year. Yes unfortunately that definition hit PPH but that was not the intent or reason we were making the criteria change. I hope we can find away to depolitize this discussion.

thanks, and i hope you will fix your article. John D.

In the future my contributions will certainly go to Planned Parenthood.  The Susan G. Komen Foundation may have made people more aware of breast cancer, but by this misguided and catering to the Far Right act, they are making themselves a losing and soon to become an irrelevant entity.

My wife and I will direct our (always small, as members of the 99%) contributions to Planned Parenthood.  The Komen's Breast Cancer people seem to have thrown reproductive rights under the bus.  Congratulations to Mayor Bloomberg for stepping up to the plate!

It's time to put a stop to the tyranny of the minority. If every time some extremist right-wing Congressman decides to hold hearings into one thing or another, good people and organizations apply the rule of guilty until proven innocent, we will be on a path toward guilt by accusation becoming the norm. That is incompatible with basic American ideals and must be resisted at every turn. http://www.panderingpoliticians.com/

I really would like to know where any of the people caterwauling about this ever got the idea that a grant-making organization had any obligation to continue to hand out money to any particular recipient! it is a laughable supposition that Komen is somehow "betraying" Planned Parenthood.

Planned Parenthood, like ANY OTHER GRANT RECIPIENT has to apply for money. The parameters of the grant, its duration, and EVERYTHING ELSE about it are in the hands of the Komen foundation ALONE. If Komen wanted to restrict its grants to one state, or to blue-eyed Armenians, or to specific income levels, or graduates of colleges with a Q in the name, IT COULD DO SO.

Planned Parenthood is a recipient. As such, it comes begging, hat in hand, conforms to any requirements Komen may have, fills out all the forms precisely and with no errors, can be tossed out at any time for any reason, and if it is lucky enough to get a grant, operates under the knowledge that it is of short and uncertain duration. And on top of all that has to compete with any and all comers who also want a shot at the same money.

This is not an entitlement, a salary, a promise, or an obligation. It's a grant.

Get over it.

The decision smacks of McCarthyism and blacklisting. To defund Planned Parenthood because a congressman decided to hold an investigation, without any basis presented or facts, is the kind of cowardice that will encourage more of the same. I hope SGK for the Cure takes the cure and reverses its decision. After all, Mubarick was dethroned by his people who risked their lives.

It is also a terrible shame that the ideologues successfully pit two worthy groups helping poor people against each other. What a victory for them!

Uhhhh - Beyond a reasonable doubt is a limitation that the justice system has to live up to - But private organizations, companies, and citizens can make their own decisions (although left-wingers generally prefer it to be the opposite way).
----Indeed, a private organization isn't bound to follow anyone else's standards.  That is what makes it so sickening that Komen would give in to a witch hunt.

I really do not understand the Susan G. Komen logic here, to cut off funding merely because Planned Parenthood is being investigated.  Nothing has been proved as to whether what they are doing is right or wrong, legal or illegal. Whatever happened to that old notion about a person being presumed innocent until proven guilty?
Komen, for a while you meant well.  It's a shame when decisions are based on religion or religious pressure, or even political pressure.  What happened to sincerity?

When this story first broke, I was appalled that SGK had capitulated to pro-choice political pressure.  But, as more and more information has come to light in the past three days (i.e., the recent hiring of a fervent anti-choice politician who publicly stated during her campaign that she would defund PP; the statements of board member Rafelli; and the inconsistent reasons given by SGK itself) all indicate to me that this was not a case of bowing to pressure, but a straightforward desire to disassociate with PP.  Brinker's FB video and her television interview with Andrea Mitchell gave  dismally inconsistent reasons for defunding, all while claiming that they are not actually defunding.  She appeared disingenuous and dishonest.  Frankly, I am glad this has all come to light.  And the light is not flattering to SGK.
I am transferring my donations from Komen to Planned Parenthood going forward.

bad choice by komen, a terribly dishonest PR spin to explain their reason, and it will, and should, negatively impact support for organization.

First and foremost, unlike the strained argument of brinker, from a mission perspective it will unquestionably reduce the ability of lower income woman, particularly in communities where PP is the only, or most accessible primary health care site to get breast care services.

second, they did not do it for principled reasons (if they had they would have declared as such) they did it in reaction to anti choice pressure from outside and within. the constantly changing story of why only confirms this. It was a great moment on TV today when after the komen CEO gave the third iteration of "the story" as to why they de-funded, Barbara Boxer calmly eviscerated her case by stating that just the day before the Komen spokespeople had said the very things the CEO was now saying wias "mischaracterization".

. it is a complex issue given their diverse supporters, but by not focusing on their primary mission they lost their way.To try and avoid controversy they showed their true colors, which are not pink but yellow and I imagine many more people will find other places to support breast cancer that also care about poor woman's access to health care.

Don't bunt, poke the ball over third base!

I'm no Tex, but I am a lefty 1st baseman. I hammer the ball to right until everyone moves over there. Then I poke the ball down the left field line to huff out a double or triple. Once I did that for a grand slam. Just open up the field.

The weight loss could have the biggest positive impact for Tex.
Playoffs? Are you kidding me? Playoffs? (Coach Mora voice). lol. This team will be a major disappointment this season. It will be sad. http://www.fromthisseat.com.

Thank you for posting this important information which clearly shows what their political agenda is. It is clearly not about the investigation of PP.

Wow, what a terrible blow to women's health and breast cancer research.
Thank you for sharing this additional proof.

"Susan G. Komen Foundation Also Stops Funding Embryonic Stem Cell Research":
http://www.care2.com/causes/susan-g-komen-foundation-also-stops-funding-...

"In addition to pulling funds from Planned Parenthood for The Susan G. Komen Foundation also decided to stop funding embryonic stem cell research centers making it fully transparent the organization has evolved from non-political non-profit to a partisan advocacy organization.

That means the loss of $3.75 million to the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, $4.5 million to the University of Kansas Medical Center, $1 million to the U.S. National Cancer Institute, $1 million to the Society for Women’s Health Research, and $600,000 to Yale University. That’s a loss of nearly $12 million dollars in research money to eradicate breast cancer this year alone.

This is a new position for the organization which had previously supported all sorts of scientific research targeted at finding a cure for breast cancer and saving women’s lives. It’s new position is that the organization will categorically no longer support any embryonic stem cell research... this is a decision they quietly slipped in during November 2011. After all, with this new pro-life branding you would think the Susan G. Komen Foundation would want to crow about it’s policy change since embryonic stem cell research is an issue near and dear to the anti-choice crowd Komen now serves."

Fact: restricting abortion does not reduce the need for and numbers of abortions; it only succeeds in more complications and deaths (see Uganda.) providing free education and contraception reduces the need for and numbers of abortions. If you want to see less abortion in this country then support planned parenthood who fights every day to provide education and affordable contraception to all women who need and want it.
Your money was NOT going to abortions:  Planned Parenthood carefully separates the money it receives for health services from the 3% of its resources it uses for abortions.
And don't buy anything made in China: they have forced abortions there.

I never knew money I gave to koman was going for abortions. I am pleased with their decision and in the future will be more careful. I think abortion should remain legal but have restrictions to help minimize it. Too bad they don't treat abortions like DUIs people would be more responsible.

THe only organization being "bullied" here is Planned Parenthood: through a flagrantly political McCarthyite "investigation."  No one is "bullying" Komen, though many millions of people have decided that they don't want to give money to an organization controlled by right-wing ideologues.
$400? You have a little while to  go before you can match the out pour of dollars granted to Planned Parenthood since this story broke. See if you can match Bloomberg's donation.
Sorry Pat, bullying is the conservative way, and it's going to be their undoing. Women from all walks of life are taking notice of how anti-women the conservative agenda is.

Bullying a private organization and telling them what to do with their money is the liberal way.  Everytime I see an article like this I send the Komen Foundation another check.  I'm up to 400 dollars now.  PP should also look for donations from people who support abortion.  That's the American way.  Not harassment.

If this really bothers you, do more than spam your Facebook friends and Twitter followers -- go to the Planned Parenthood website and make a donation.  Internet outrage can be a great tool, but it doesn't hurt to walk the walk, either.
Yes, that's why it's so important to have separation of church and state.

They have not stopped funding "breast services." They have stopped giving money to Planned Parenthood (which neither is the only mammogram in town nor in fact provides mammograms most of the time). They have a right to do so. They are still funding breast cancer research and mammograms, just not by giving cash to an organization that already has a billion dollars and doesn't provide the services anyway.

Hey, here's an idea: let's give some of that foundation money to smaller organizations that would like to help women pay for mammograms but don't already have a BILLION dollars!

I am saddened by the Komen organization's decision to stop funding breast services.  These exams have a real impact on the women that planned parenthood serves.  I am a practicing christian and I can find no excuse to endanger the lives of mother's, sister's. and daughter's because you don't agree with some of the other services being offered.  My grandmother had a saying...don't cut off your nose to spite your face.  Not everything has to be an all or nothing.  It's time to take politics and religion out of healthcare.
